fields.descriptive_line: Portrait miniature of a woman wearing masque costume, probably a daughter of Elizabeth of Bohemia, watercolour on vellum, painted by Nathaniel Thach, 1649.

fields.name: Royal Academy Winter Exhibition of British Art
The Monarchs of Great Britain and Ireland

fields.physical_description:
Head and shoulders portrait, turned slightly to left and looking to front.  The sitter is dressed in masque costume.  Features in long, slight, loose hatches of brown and sanguine shaded with blue and grey; red for the lips, black in the eyes and a white highlight in the sitter's left eye; all on a very pale carnation ground; hair in pale brown wash, modelled in dark brown and grey; head-dress in bright scarlet wash partly transparent, modelled in black and white; dress modelled in grey-brown heightened with white over a pale grey wash; shawl loosely hatched in pink, scarlet, yellow and blue; blue, grey and white for the pearls; metallic gold highlights in the jewelled clasp and dress border, but no burnished silver in the stones; background in transparent pale blue wash, loosely hatched horizontally in grey; remains of a gold marginal strip; on vellum put down on pasteboard. 
 
<u>Frame:</u> Nineteenth- or early twentieth-century copper-gilt locket with a plain convex back, fitting an oval made of double-toothed strip within a rope-twist of wires soldered around the rim; a convex glass under the toothed strip at the front; the hanger a flat loop arranged to simulate continuity with the two diminishing spirals of four-and-a-half turns.
fields.title: A Woman in Masque Costume, probably a daughter of Elizabeth of Bohemia
fields.materials_techniques: Watercolour on vellum put down on pasteboard

fields.bibliography: Murdoch, John. Seventeenth-century English Miniatures in the collection of the Victoria and Albert Museum. London: The Stationery Office, 1997. Cat.43, pp. 86-88. Full Citation: "43 A Woman in Masque Costume, probably a daughter of Elizabeth of Bohemia 1649 P2-1969 Oval 59 x 48 mm Features in long, slight, loose hatches of brown and sanguine shaded with blue and grey; red for the lips, black in the eyes and a white highlight in the sitter's left eye; all on a very pale carnation ground; hair in pale brown wash, modelled in dark brown and grey; head-dress in bright scarlet wash partly transparent, modelled in black and white; dress modelled in grey-brown heightened with white over a pale grey wash; shawl loosely hatched in pink, scarlet, yellow and blue; blue, grey and white for the pearls; metallic gold highlights in the jewelled clasp and dress border, but no burnished silver in the stones; background in transparent pale blue wash, loosely hatched horizontally in grey; remains of a gold marginal strip; on vellum put down on pasteboard. Condition: Rubbed with polished spots; faded; engrimed; the gold marginal strip lost in two-thirds of the oval and rubbed into the background upper right. Signed: In black, lower right: NThach/ 164[9] (the N and T conjoined - see A in Appendix 2). Inscribed on the back in graphite: Henrietta/Dss of Orleans/Daughter of Charles 1. Frame: Nineteenth- or early twentieth-century copper-gilt locket with a plain convex back, fitting an oval made of double-toothed strip within a rope-twist of wires soldered around the rim; a convex glass under the toothed strip at the front; the hanger a flat loop arranged to simulate continuity with the two diminishing spirals of four-and-a-half turns. Provenance: One of the 'Stuart Group' of miniatures deposited by James II with Louis XIV (see Oliver, Cat. No. 12 [P.27-1975] for details). Edwards-Heathcote sale, Christies 13 June 1928, lot 53, bt by Major RMO de la Hey; his sale, Sotheby's 27 May 1968, lot 53, bt Leggat, from whom purchased by the Museum, 1969. Exhibited: According to Walsh and Jeffree 1975-6, on display at the South Kensington Museum in 1874; New Gallery 1889, unnumbered; New Gallery, Regent Street, The Monarchs of Great Britain and Ireland, 1901-2,no. 234; RA 1934, no. 1034; Edinburgh 1965, no. 48 pl. 19; Geffrye Museum 1975-6, no. 56 (repro.); New Haven etc. 1981-2, no. 43. Literature: Gower 1882, vol. H, unnumbered pages, under "Trentham Vicarage', no. 10 (repro.); Foster 1903, vol. H, p. 56;Williamson 1904, vol.I, p. 32 (as Henrietta Maria, Duchess of Orleans by N Thach); Foster 1926, p. 294; Long 1929, p. 433; B S Long, 'The Exhibition of British Art: Miniatures', Burlington Magazine, LXIV (January 1934), pp. 73-4, pI. VHB; Schidloff 1964, vol. H, p. 807; Foskett 1972, vol.I, p. 544; Foskett 1979, pp. 116-17, pl. 22C; Summary Catalogue, 1981, p. 59; Murdoch 1981, pp. 140-2, col. pl. 19f; R P Edwards, 'A Group of Stuart Miniatures and their History', Notes and Queries, vol. 31, no. 3 (September 1984),pp.352-6. This miniature is a copy after a painting in the style of Honthorst but attributed to his pupil the Princess Louise Hollandine in the Museum Wasserburg at Anholt, Denmark. (1) The Anholt picture is identified as the Princess Sophia (1630-1714), the twelfth child of Elizabeth of Bohemia and mother of the future George I of Great Britain. Sophia's appearance is independently quite well established.(2) TheAnholt picture does not seem to be necessarily of the same person as in these images, but family likenesses and the large formulaic element in the portraiture of these 'Bohemian' ladies makes distinction between them very difficult. The former identification of this miniature, as in the inscription quoted above, was as the Princess Henrietta Anne, Duchess of Orleans , daughter of Charles 1. She, however, was born in 1644, only five years before the date of the miniature. A sensible emendation of the inscription would lead to Henrietta Marie (b.1626, the ninth child of Elizabeth of Bohemia), who married Sigismund Radgozki of Transylvania six months before her death of fever in 1651. Her appearance is recorded by Honthorst (3) and possibly in a miniature at Windsor (4) attributed to Thach; the images seem compatible with both of the present miniatures but, as with Sophia, distinguishing likenesses of these sisters seems an impossible task. The latest suggestion of Anne of Gonzaga (1616-1684), depends on comparison with an engraving 'probably that by Rousselet' - a suggestion credited in the V&A cataloguing (5) to Goulding, but without reference. Anne was the second daughter of Charles de Gonzague, Duc de Nevers. A Catholic, her marriage in 1645 to Prince Edward (1625-1663), Elizabeth of Bohemia's eighth child, led to their alienation from the Protestant Court of The Hague and their residence in Paris. Both culturally and geographically, therefore, Anne seems only a remote possibility. Furthermore, she was born in 1616 and as a woman of thirty-three in 1649 seems less plausible than any of her younger sisters-in-law. The great pity lying behind this confusion is the fate of the Craven family collection of 'Bohemian' portraits, imprudently allowed to be dispersed at auction over the years, especially between 1968 and 1984. The Honthorst literature is generally inadequate in relation to his portraiture, and particularly insensitive to the symbolic iconography that he deployed as a Court painter to the Stadtholder in The Hague after 1637.(6) Rosenberg and Slive, for example, comment on Honthurst's contribution to the decoration of Huis ten Bosch (the Dutch royal palace) for Amalia van Solms, the Stadtholder's widow, in 1649-50: 'These allegorical pictures are a document of the emptiness of official courtly taste at a time when Hals worked in increased isolation and Rembrandt was at the beginning of his mature period.'(7) Certainly the work that he did for the Bohemian exiles, as it were in parallel to his work for the Dutch Court, seems to belong to a different world from that of Rembrandt and Hals. The last images of Frederick V before his death in 1632 show him in medallic profile as a Roman Emperor" and in state robes, with orb and sceptre as King of Bohernia, (8) both images recalling the ambitions of 1613-21 rather than the realities of exile in the middle of the Thirty Years' War. In English terms, the iconography is Jacobean rather than Carolean - Isaac Oliver rather than Van Dyck. The portraiture is in that sense backward-looking, but it is so in order to make the important political point of the continuity of the struggle against the Catholic Hapsburg hegemony. Similarly, the masque costume evidently worn by the sitter for this miniature, looks back to the culture of the English Court ante bellum. In The Hague, the date 1649 is Significant as the year in which the Treaty of Westphalia (1648) opened the way for the return of Charles Louis (1616/17-1680) to his father's electoral state of the Palatinate. This masque costume with its feathered head-dress may even Signal an allusion in Court festivities to the dresses designed by Inigo Jones for the Masque of the Middle Temple: 'their robes were tucked up before, strange hoods of feathers and scallops about their necks, and on their heads turbans, stuck with several coloured feathers ... On their heads high sprigged feathers, compassed in coronets, like the Virginian princes' , (10) This was the masque put on by the Inns of Court to celebrate the marriage of the Princess Elizabeth to Frederick V in 1613, before she herself accompanied her husband to the Palatinate at the start of the whole Bohemian adventure. 1 Letter from Dr Avon Rohr, May 1981, department files; Rudiger Joppien, 'The Dutch Vision of Brazil, Johan Maurits van Nassau-Siegen 1604-79: A humanist Prince in Europe and Brazil, Essays on the Occasion of the Tercenterary of his Death, ed. E van den Boogart, (The Hague, 1979), p. 349, repro. pl.159. 2 See for example R Strong, The Winter Queen (NPG, 1963), no. 65, the Dieussart bust, repro. pl. Vllb, and especially the portraits by Honthorst formerly in the Craven Collection, sold Sotheby's 27 November 1968,lots 47, 48 and 49. 3 The Winter Queen, repro. pl. VIa. 4 Cust 1910, case 44/19. 5 Department files. 6 But Frederik von Kretschmar has made a careful study of at least the Anglo-Dutch component of the Craven Collection. 7 Dutch Art and Architecture 1600-1800,ed. P Rosenbergand S Slive (1966),p. 29. 8 1631; sold Sotheby's 27 November 1968, lot 37. 9 c.1632; sold Sotheby's 27 November 1968, lot 35. 10 S Orgel and R Strong, Inigo Jones: The Theatre of the Stuart Court (London, Berkeley and Los Angeles 1973), vol. I, p. 256; for the suggested derivation of this feather costume from Cesare Vecelli, Habiti antichi et moderni di tutto il mondo . (Venice, 1598), see ibid., vol.I, p. 262, fig. 34."
fields.history_note: <u>Provenance:</u> One of the 'Stuart Group' of miniatures deposited by James II with Louis XIV (see Oliver, Cat. No. 12 for details). Edwards-Heathcote sale, Christies 13 June 1928, lot 53, bt by Major RMO de la Hey; his sale, Sotheby's 27 May 1968, lot 53, bt Leggat,from whom purchased by the Museum, 1969.
